metadata.titleEn: Dataset of concentrations of mercury (Hg) in the soil of the southern Tibetan Plateau（2007-2009）
metadata.description: This dataset includes the concentrations and spatial pattern of mercury (Hg) in the soil of the southern Tibetan Plateau. Two hundred thirty nine soil samples were collected, and cold vapor atomic fluorescence spectrophotometry (CVAFS) was used to analyse the Hg contents. The limit of detection (LOD) for this method is 1.8 ng/g. The standard reference material, soil GB GSS-2, which is supplied by National Institute of Metrology P.R.China, was also analyzed for assessing the accuracy of this method, and the recoveries of this method were 84%-103%. This dataset will provide the informations of soil Hg contamination and background values over the southern Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions: In .excel format, can be opened and analysed in Microsoft EXCEL software.

Quantification.Question: How many soil samples were collected for measuring total mercury concentration in the Tibetan Plateau?

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations can be inferred regarding the collection and measurement of soil mercury concentrations in high-altitude regions like the southern Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The collection and measurement of soil mercury concentrations in high-altitude regions like the southern Tibetan Plateau involve gathering surface soil samples and using wet digestion followed by atomic fluorescence spectrometry to determine total mercury content. The method has a detection limit of 1.8 ng/g. Quality control is maintained by using standard soil (GB GSS-2) as a reference material, achieving a recovery rate of 84-103%. These methodological considerations ensure accurate and reliable data, which can be vital for assessing mercury pollution and transboundary pollution influences in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary goals of collecting and analyzing soil total mercury concentration and spatial distribution data in the southern Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goals of collecting and analyzing soil total mercury concentration and spatial distribution data in the southern Tibetan Plateau include establishing a reference dataset for soil mercury pollution levels and background values in the region, and providing foundational data for assessing the impact of transboundary pollutant transport from South Asia on the Tibetan Plateau.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing soil samples for total mercury concentration in the southern Tibetan region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing soil samples for total mercury concentration in the southern Tibetan region include collecting 239 surface soil samples, using wet digestion and atomic fluorescence methods to determine the total mercury content, and ensuring the detection limit is 1.8 ng/g. The process uses standard soil (GB GSS-2) as a reference material with an experimental recovery rate of 84-103%, ensuring strict data quality control.
